ThingDef.label: Colt Walker
ThingDef.description: 1847 Colt Walker. Samuel Colt's second-ever handgun design was this Texas behemoth, The Colt-Walker Revolver was designed to replace the old single-shot saddle pistols while still having similar power, enough to kill a horse in one shot. One of the largest most powerful black-powder revolvers developed, pushing a 44 slug with 60 grains of black powder.\n\n"Well are ya' gonna pull those pistols or whistle Dixie?"

ThingDef.label: Colt M1847 Walker Silver
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .44 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.description: Caliber: .44 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.description: Caliber: .44 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.label: Colt 1851 Navy
ThingDef.description: Colt 1851 Navy. One of the most popular military revolver designs both in the US and the export market. .36 caliber bore with an excellent balance and grip, just point and shoot.\n\n"You see in this world there's two kinds of people my friend. Those with loaded guns, and those who dig."

ThingDef.label: Colt M1851 Navy Nickel
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .36 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.label: Colt M1851 Navy US Marshall
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .36 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.label: 36 Pepperbox
ThingDef.description: 36 Pepperbox. An early simplistic double-action pistol. Can easily be concealed and fired from the hip, has no sights, and is hard to hit anything at range. This model is a .36 caliber 4-shot. \n\n"Five Aces and one big problem"

ThingDef.label: Walch Revolver
ThingDef.description: Walch Navy Revolver. Patented by John Walch in 1859, this is a .36 caliber revolver using superimposed chambers, meaning that each of the six chambers could hold two shots, for a total of 12 rounds before reloading. Two hammers and two side-by-side triggers, with the trigger for the front loading being positioned slightly ahead of the rear loadâ€™s trigger, to help ensure that they are fired in the correct order. two shots can be fired in very quick succession with this arramgement.\n\n"Twelve shots... More than enough to kill anything that moves."

ThingDef.label: Starr Revolver
ThingDef.description: Starr Revolver. An early development of a true double-action revolver, rather then cocking the gun by manual pulling the hammer down, the hammer is cocked via the trigger pull. Less popular then single action models due to its fragility.\n\n"You just shot an unarmed man"-"He should have armed himself"

ThingDef.label: LeMat Revolver
ThingDef.description: LeMat. Nicknamed the "grapeshot revolver", the LeMat features a 9-shot cylinder and a centerline support combined into a shotgun barrel capable of firing a 20 bore shot. A favorite of eccentric officers.\n\n"King Cotton, The Leader of All"

ThingDef.label: Colt M1860 Army
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .44 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.description: Caliber: .36 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.description: Caliber: .36 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.description: Caliber: .36 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.description: Caliber: .36 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.label: Colt Single Action Army
ThingDef.description: The gun that won the West. The Colt 1873 Single Action Army, or "Peacemaker" is one of the most iconic and widespread revolver of American west. Its a good and reliable weapon but quite slow to reload. Chambered in .45 Colt.

ThingDef.label: Colt 1878 "Lightning"
ThingDef.description: The Colt model 1878 "Lightning", a double-action revolver and a gun of choice for old West gunslingers, including Doc Hollyday and Billy the Kid.

ThingDef.label: Colt Open Top
ThingDef.description: Colt 1871-72. Simple single-action revolver in the low-power .44 rimfire round.

ThingDef.label: Remington 1875
ThingDef.description: Remington 1875. Single-action revolver chambered in the 44-40 carbine cartridge. A convenient sidearm for your 44-40 rifle.

ThingDef.label: Remington New Army
ThingDef.description: Remington 1858 New Army. The Remington revolver uses a one-piece frame that has more strength than older designs, increasing durability, and innate accuracy. This model can fire powerfull .45 Colt metallic cartridge alongside .44 blackpowder balls. An empty cylinder can be swapped with a loaded spare, leading to lightning-fast reloads.\n\n"When I'm paid I always see the job through"

ThingDef.label: S&W Model 3 Schofield
ThingDef.description: S&W Model 3 Schofield. The Schofield was used by US cavalry due to its quick eject mechanism. Chambered in .45 Schofield, a slightly less powerful version of .45 Colt.

ThingDef.label: Lil Deuce pistol
ThingDef.description: Lil Deuce pistol. 2-Bore Percussion Pistol, when you want somebody to disappear.

ThingDef.label: S&W Model 3 Russian
ThingDef.description: S&W Model 3 Russian. Ancient single action-break action pistol. It has a slow fire rate with adequate firepower, the one advantage is that the user can aim faster because of the very high ergonomics of the design.

ThingDef.label: Nagant Revolver
ThingDef.description: Nagant M1895. Ancient double-action revolver. The gun uses a 7-round cylinder that loads one by one via an ejection rod. The old revolver also takes advantage of a gas-sealed cartridge/cylinder, giving higher velocity than others in its class. Owning one used to be a sign of power.
